title: Do you need to be good at math in order to become an air traffic controller? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, but the type of people who make good controllers are often the type of people who are pretty good at mental arithmetic and such like. Its definitely a job which requires “brain power” and concentration. In ATC training, there is a little maths, but it’s high school level. In operation, controllers don’t use maths in their day to day work. Speed/time calculations are often cited as an example of maths being used by controllers, but with experience a controller is using memory rather than calculating. For example - a flight at a groundspeed of 300 knots will cover 5 miles in a minute, the controller will use this knowledge to predict it’s future position relative to another aircraft. He/she is not really doing the arithmetic in their head, they are recalling the results from previous experience.

not necessarily, though it does seem that people with mathematical ways of thinking are also better at controlling aircraft… generally, to be a good controller one needs to: be good at solving problems rapidlybe able to pivot to solution 2 when solution 1 isn’t workingbe good at 4 D ( including time) visualization / projectionable to operate effectively under pressureNowadays, computers tend to do the math leaving the decision making to the humans.

Yes and no… The type of math you need to be good at is you need to be able to figure out quickly how fast two aircraft may be converging, and other distance and physical things like that. You don’t need to know how to solve some calculus equation or anything like that. One of the most important attributes for an Air Traffic Controller is to have very good spatial thinking.

Max has a good answer, I'll just add a bit.Forget calc, algebra. Trig and geometry are helpful, in visualizing angles, but not using numbers or calculating anything. A qualitative idea is all that's needed. Quantitative stuff involves a numerical answer; a controller usually has no time or need for a calculator...As Max said, the big picture without any numbers, is best. Two different types of math...
Being able to mentally "see" trig and geometry, and to a lesser extent physics, is important. Knowing mathematical formulas is not.
